Ken,

OMG...this is completely different than the understanding I had.  This seems MUCH more reasonable.
 This means the weight mutation evaluations *are* getting vastly more time than I had understood
the default NEAT parameters were giving.

BTW, sorry I have not been able to reply to your response.  I really appreciate your taking the
time to respond in depth.  If all goes well, I will get some time to reply this evening.


Jim


--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <djames@g...> wrote:
> > On Sun, 06 Jun 2004 21:59:46 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> 
> wrote:
> > > I think most NEAT implementations perform only one structural 
> mutation
> > > at a time. 
> > 
> > It would be a good time to clarify this.  If your add connection
> > mutation rate is 0.02 and you've got 100 individuals, and there are
> > 100,000 possible places for a new connection to be added, there 
> should
> > be a total of 2,000 new connections added.  Are you saying that 
> only
> > 100 should be added, one for each individual?  And that if an
> > individual has already had a connection added, then no add node
> > mutations are allowed to act upon it (or vice versa if your add 
> node
> > mutation operators are carried out first)?
> > 
> > This is not my understanding of how NEAT works.  Ken?
> > 
> 
> Ah, we may have hit on a reason for some of our disagreements!  The 
> add_connection mutation rate is the probability that an *individual 
> genome* might have a single connection added.  In other words, in a 
> population of 100 individuals and a 0.02 rate, you would expect to 
> get on average 2 new connections over the entire population in a 
> single generation.
> 
> In addition, it is also true that only one add connection mutation 
> can happen to a single individual in a generation.
> 
> It seems to me that your interpetation was that the mutation rate is 
> on a "per empty slot" basis.  That's radically different than my 
> NEAT implementation...interesting though that that works at all...is 
> that how ANJI has been working?
> 
> But anyway absolutely Colin is right: one structural mutation at a 
> time is the usual rule.
> 
> ken
> 
> 
> 
>
